text: 3d bioprinting is the process of
directly depositing material to create a
tissue or organ from scratch my name is
Scott slimmer
I'm the lab manager in Jennifer Lewis's
research group at Harvard University in
the VESA Institute by being able to
directly print functional tissues one
could have I think a much more
substantive approach to both
pharmaceutical drug screening as well as
tissue engineering and that's what our
group is trying to do the biggest
challenge in 3d bioprinting is arguably
creating complex vasculature vasculature
is essential because it supports and
pervades human tissue and without it
cells in the bulk of a structural die
cells have metabolic needs they consume
nutrients they produce waste and you
have to be able to deliver fresh
nutrients once those cells exhaust the
nearby a supply and you also have to be
able to wash away the waste so it
doesn't accumulate and suffocate the
cells we've developed a new fugitive ink
that allows you to print a
three-dimensional object encapsulate it
with a cell Laden hydrogel and then just
by simply cooling you can liquefy the
fugitive ink and then wash it away
the fugitive ink we used was a planet a
parodic so very unique material and then
it has an atypical thermal transition at
higher temperatures it's a gel and at
lower temperatures it liquefies so what
we can do is print at room temperature
first we print a p-- laurent ik network
that's going to become the vasculature a
room temperature it's solid and it
maintains its shape then over that we
can pour our matrix our gelatin
methacrylate at room temperature it's
liquid like so it pours over and encases
the printed floor onic very well we can
take that entire structure then and cool
it down two things happen is it's
cooling down first the gelatin matrix
goes from liquid like to solid light at
the same time the plur onic goes from
solid like to liquid light we can apply
a light vacuum to the end of the quranic
network and simply remove the liquid
parodic and that will use empty channels
within our solid matrix that we can fill

network we're interested in basically
taking our skills and mature
assembly and three-dimensional printing
